search_result.title: How one Delaware songbird can predict hurricane season better ...
search_result.text:
WILMINGTON, Del. – This year, a little bird signaled a Delaware researcher that the 2019 tropical storm season in the Atlantic Ocean was going to be more active than normal.

“If you think about it, it makes a lot of sense,” said Christopher Heckscher of Delaware State University, who found the link between veery thrushes and tropical storm activity.

“These birds have evolved in concert with storms in the fall, during their migratory period for, theoretically, thousands of years if not more. It would make sense that they would, at some point, get in sync with the climate at a larger global scale.”

For two decades, Heckscher has been studying Delaware’s densest population of veery thrushes, a cinnamon-colored songbird with a spotted chest that migrates every spring from the southern Amazon basin to northern breeding grounds that stretch from Delaware to Canada.

Over the years he has watched and tracked one population of veeries nestling into the forests of White Clay Creek State Park each spring. Even though the species travels thousands of miles for this moment, they only ever raise one clutch, or one successful nest of usually two to four chicks.

“I started to notice that in some years the birds were stopping their breeding season earlier than other years,” the ornithologist, entomologist and environmental science professor said.

He began to wonder why after a few years of shorter breeding seasons. Did they not have enough food? Was it because the weather was too dry or too hot?

Eventually, he started looking at what advantage the birds would have by shortening their nesting season. That’s when he thought to look at tropical storm activity, which occurs along their long migratory route.

“It turns out that in years they stop breeding earlier, there’s more tropical storm activity on their migration route,” Heckscher said. “I thought of that idea, I tested the hypothesis, I looked at the data, but I really wasn’t expecting there to be any relationship there.

"And it was a really strong relationship.”

Nearly 20 years of data showed Heckscher that not only does the length of the veery’s breeding season relate to future tropical storm activity, but the average number of eggs in each nest could also signal whether the season will be normal, slow or overly active. He found that females produce more eggs when an active hurricane season is in store.

“The chances of this relationship being coincidental, in my opinion, are pretty small," he said. “We don’t know for sure that the relationship is real, but there is a relationship between what the birds are doing and the following tropical storm season.”

In late May, NOAA predicted that this year’s Atlantic tropical storm season, which lasts from June 1 to Nov. 30, would be near normal. It called for up to 15 named storms, two to four of which would become major hurricanes.

What's in a name? Here's how naming hurricanes works

Meanwhile, the veery thrush data from this spring indicated the season would be a bit more active than normal.

By their next update in August, NOAA changed its prediction for the season and increased the chances of an above-normal season with up to 17 named storms. As of Nov. 1, there have been 17 named storms and three major hurricanes.

The birds had it right all along.

“Which is pretty incredible if you think about it because these birds, the timing of their breeding season is determined in May and June, and that storm activity is happening in September, October, November,” Heckscher said.

Last year, Heckscher published a paper on his songbird and hurricane findings, but the data has yet to be used in NOAA’s forecasting. That won’t happen until researchers such as Heckscher can find some missing puzzle pieces.

His research also will be featured in a Netflix documentary expected to come out next year, he said.

While the link between these thrushes and tropical activity is clear, he said, it remains a mystery how the thrushes are able to sense future weather patterns as accurately or better than advanced meteorological super computers.

Heckscher has a few guesses, but it will take more of research and studies to pinpoint how the birds are able to predict weather patterns for their own safety, and whether other migratory species are able to do the same.

He said there's a possibility that the birds can somehow sense sea-surface temperatures – a huge factor in hurricane development and strength, on their journey north. Or that maybe precipitation or other environmental factors in their wintering grounds could be providing cues that humans haven't yet picked up on.

“Whatever it is, it’s something that they’ve already figured it out by mid-May at the latest, really,” he said. “It’s just opened up so many other questions. How do they know this?”

How hurricanes form:Infographic: An inside look at the birth and power of hurricanes

Don't let your guard down:Are Category 5 hurricanes such as Dorian the 'new normal'?

How NOAA predicts tropical storm seasons

Until researchers can figure out how the veeries predict future weather patterns, public safety relies on the modeling and forecasting provided by federal agencies.

Even after decades of fine-tuning, there always remains a certain level of uncertainty in forecasts, said meteorologist Matthew Rosencrats with NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center.

NOAA uses a combination of what experts call statistical and dynamical tools, which look at patterns of sea-surface temperatures and upper level winds, as well as computer modeling, to help predict how many tropical storm systems could develop months in advance.

Those forecasts are delivered in July and again in August for a season that peaks around Sept. 10, he said.

While Rosencrats said he hasn’t seen Heckscher’s study and data, and researchers would have to pinpoint the physical and biochemical bases that drive the veery’s ability to forecast tropical storms before it could be helpful in a more public way.

“If we could ever figure out the biological and statistical reasoning why, it could be used,” he said. “The wildlife of Delmarva, they’re really important to the whole ecology of the region, to the economy and to tourism.”

Follow reporter Maddy Lauria on Twitter @MaddyinMilford.

search_result.title: New condos delight those with disabilities
search_result.text:
Beth Miller

The News Journal

Federal guidelines are pushing to move people with disabilities out of group homes%2C facilities

Homes For Life provides residences for people with cognitive disabilities

State%2C agencies provide support as needed

WILMINGTON – Joe Flacco was there on Day One, present with all the glory a plastic NFL figurine can bear and placed in front of Jeff Jones' living-room television.

The news here is that Jeff Jones has a living room in his own place – his first place, which at 38 years of age comes none too soon. Jones says he has been waiting for moving day his entire life so, of course, one of his heroes, the Baltimore Ravens' quarterback and University of Delaware alum, would have a prominent role.

Jones is one of three young adults who have moved into neighboring condominiums at Justison Landing on Wilmington's riverfront. The furnished units were donated by the Homes For Life Foundation to The Arc of Delaware, a nonprofit that serves as an advocate and resource for those with intellectual and cognitive disabilities.

Jones and Alexandra Jahn, 36 – who is moving into a condo next to his – have worked for Bank of America and its predecessor, MBNA America, for 15 years.

Dayon Stevens, 28, who is blind, is Jones' new roommate and hopes to find work at one of the many businesses nearby.

All three arrive in these independent units under a new set of regulations from the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) that govern how and where federal support for home- and community-based services will be provided for people with disabilities.

The feds are moving everything toward greater independence – individual choice, community integration, and self-determination – and away from anything that looks like an institution or a sequestered world where only those with certain disabilities reside.

The rules reflect the mandates of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the 1999 U.S. Supreme Court ruling known as Olmstead, which said people with disabilities must be able to live in the least-restrictive environment appropriate for them.

"Justison Landing is for people who are quite independent, people who don't need 24-hour support," said Jane Gallivan, director of the state Division of Developmental Disabilities Services (DDDS). "It's an ideal setting and they can take full advantage of the wonderful amenities in that area."

If community integration is the goal, that Flacco figurine is probably near the proverbial end zone.

New philosophy

These two-bedroom units are the 26th and 27th residential properties donated by Homes For Life, the foundation created by Micki and Lanny Edelsohn to provide homes for those with cognitive disabilities. Their son, Robert, lives with several roommates in one of the homes on Wilmington's Bancroft Parkway.

The condominiums – worth about $190,000 each – were deeded to The Arc of Delaware, which serves as a sort of turbocharged landlord, providing extended services to residents of its 82 properties that go far beyond leases and minor repairs.

Tenants sign their own leases. A service provider – Community Systems Inc. in this case – supports the residents with assistance according to their needs, and ensures all systems are working well. And the state verifies eligibility for state and federal money, compliance with state and federal requirements, and provides case management and other services.

Federal regulations now require residences to be in community settings wherever appropriate, though precise definitions of what that means still are under construction.

Delaware has until March 2015 to give CMS its plan for how it will award home- and community-based funds and it has until 2019 to comply with the new regulations, Gallivan said.

CMS is providing information on its new regulations little by little, Gallivan said.

"Once we get as much guidance as possible, we will begin to put a plan together," she said. "They want to know - how are you going to evaluate the settings you have? That's not only for residential, but also for day services."

State officials will invite significant public input as the plan is developed, she said.

The regulations have some non-negotiables already, though.

For example, one major rule is that no programs that get federal waiver money can be located on or adjacent to the grounds of a public institution, such as the Stockley Center in Sussex County or the Gov. Bacon Center near Delaware City. Those who have lived on those grounds have been moving into community settings for some time, Gallivan said.

The regulations also govern what happens in those community settings. Residents must have the liberty to choose their day's activities instead of having to follow the dictates of staff.

For example, "if I want to hang out in my PJs to watch TV until noon on Saturdays, I should have that option," Gallivan said. "It's my home."

It's not supposed to be an institution.

Exciting times

Justison Landing sits along the Christina River, amid a host of urban neighborhood amenities – a major cinema complex, a minor league ballpark, shops, restaurants, many small businesses, parks and room to roam.

This past week, Jones and Stevens went together to the Polish Festival, where Jones was winning lots of prizes at the arcade, according to Jennifer Tymes, program director for Community Systems Inc.

Already, Tymes said, Jones had cooked dinner for everyone at his place.

His mother, Suellen Jones of Bear, helped him move in. It's the first time her son has not lived at home or in a group home, she said, and he is excited.

"I've been in a group home for 16 years," Jeff Jones said with a grin as he unpacked a box. "I've been bugging them and bugging them and I finally got out. I've been really looking forward to this – being on my own and lots of fun."

It's a bit different from his mom's perspective.

"It's a little frightening," she said, "but we'll wait and see. ... We'll see how well it works."

Her husband helped to persuade her the time was right for their son.

"We're getting up in years," she said, "and we're not going to be here forever."

Getting their own place is a significant milestone.

"They're graduating," said Michelle Thompson, state case manager for all three. "It's the excitement that they're coming into their own now. ... Seeing their faces when they see their new condos, no less. This is theirs. They've worked hard to overcome all the barriers. They have surpassed everything people have expected of them."

There are fresh memories in Delaware, though, of a recent horror captured on video. The video showed a series of beatings kids delivered to a young man with intellectual disabilities in a Newark neighborhood

It was a disturbing, frightening incident and a reminder that life in the community is sometimes perilous – never more so than for someone with a disability.

"We have to have a strong self-advocacy system where we are helping individuals living on their own or semi-independently to know what to do and how to be assertive," Gallivan said. "We have to be cautious. There has to be a balance. With your rights come responsibilities. People do have the right to live in the community and be as independent as possible. But we have to be sure they have the tools they need to deal with situations when they come up."

Some will encounter rejection, too, just because they are different or someone judges them to be "less than."

"There is a lot of misinformation out there and a lot of misconceptions about persons with disabilities – and those with intellectual disabilities in particular," said Terry Olson, executive director of The Arc of Delaware. "We try to educate folks, be positive and supportive, and we try to be a good neighbor."

There are many challenges, costs, and concerns to address.

But watching Alexandra Jahn twirl excitedly in her new bedroom, talk about where her desk might go and what she might do with the walls, smile and twirl and talk about more possibilities – it made Micki Edelsohn of Homes For Life a bit emotional. Again.

"As a person, a mom, and a taxpaying citizen, this is a very expensive proposition, caring for a population that is very vulnerable," she said. "But it's up to us as a society to do what we need to do to ensure people are cared for properly and getting the right supports.

"I will work with the state and anyone who wants to work with me to try and find solutions for all people."

Contact Beth Miller at (302) 324-2784 or bmiller@delawareonline.com. Follow on Twitter @BMiller57 or on Facebook.

search_result.title: Woman dies following Wilmington assault; second fatal attack in city
search_result.text:
A 31-year-old woman has been charged in connection with a robbery-turned-assault in Wilmington that left another woman dead last week.

City police were called to the 200 block of N. Lombard St. just after 9 p.m. on Oct. 24 after receiving reports of an unresponsive woman. There, they found 49-year-old Lisa Fakis badly hurt.

She was rushed to the hospital, where she was pronounced dead, police said.

Through their investigation, detectives learned that Fakis had been assaulted during a robbery. The department did not say how she was attacked or whether a weapon was used.

Following an "area search," police arrested Laverne Sealey and charged her for the attack, the department said. She faces first degree robbery and second degree assault charges.

RELATED:Meet Delaware State Police's soon-to-be leader as Col. Melissa Zebley retires

She's being held at Delores J. Baylor Women’s Correctional Institution on $140,000 cash-only bail.

Wilmington police said investigators are "working with the Delaware Department of Justice to upgrade her charges in connection with this incident."

Second fatal assault in city in less than a week

Fakis was the second person killed in Wilmington last week in an assault.

The first, 60-year-old Edward Wiggins, was attacked about 2 p.m. on Oct. 20 in the 2100 block of N. Market St.

A brief news release issued two days after Wiggins' death did not say when police learned of the attack or what he was attacked with. Police also did not provide any details about the circumstances of the attack and made no note as to whether it was a random assault or targeted.

READ:After man fatally attacked in Wilmington, city police provide little information

Police continue to investigate that incident.

search_result.title: Instant analysis: Phillies overmatched by upstart Marlins after long ...
search_result.text:
PHILADELPHIA – The Phillies had waited nearly four months for this opener delayed by the coronavirus pandemic.

And it was so much different than anything the Phillies, or the rest of major league baseball, had experienced before.

There were no fans in the stands Friday night, nor will there be for the foreseeable future. That might have been a good thing for the Phillies, who would have been resoundingly booed when they fell behind by four runs in the sixth.

PHILLIES SHOW UNITY:Phillies wear "Black Lives Matter" T-shirts, stand for anthem while holding long black ribbon

Perhaps the only similarity would have been the near-empty ballpark by the end of the Phillies' 5-2 loss to the Miami Marlins in the season opener for both teams.

All things Phillies: Latest Philadelphia Phillies news, schedule, roster, stats, injury updates and more.

The game began with high hopes, even though the usual pomp and circumstance from an opening day were missing, and the game was mostly played in silence.

"We’ve been in spring training for a long time, and I’m ready for real games to get started," said Joe Girardi, who managed his first game for the Phillies on Friday. "Obviously, there was a lot of excitement coming into the game. It's disappointing. Everyone wants to win opening day."

HARPER'S VOICE:In his second season, Bryce Harper is getting vocal about Phillies' future

The only audible sounds were some fake piped-in cheering (no booing), players calling for fly balls, and a few fans beyond the outfield gates booing when Phillies pitcher Aaron Nola gave up a two-run homer to Jesus Aguilar in the sixth.

"It was pretty neat, the fans outside center field, yelling and screaming," Girardi said with a laugh. "It's something I won't forget."

LEGACY LIVING ON:Related to baseball giant, Hunter puts heart into new Ingram league

It was hard to tell if there was urgency from the lack of noise in the ballpark, but there should have been among the players.

"It's a 60-game season and you don't really have time to coast," Nola said.

That's because Major League Baseball announced Thursday that it was adding three more teams to the playoffs, for a total of eight from each league.

That opened up some hope for a Phillies team that hasn't had a winning season since 2011.

EAGLES TOP 5:Eagles' 5 most important players for the 2020 season: No. 3 Javon Hargrave

But there are only 60 games in the season, and losing an opener to the Marlins, who lost 105 games last season, was not a good start.

All of this will take some getting used to, even though there isn't much time for that. Some of that includes social distancing in the clubhouse. Some players, such as shortstop Didi Gregorius and first baseman Rhys Hoskins, wore masks on the field.

That's something players have dealt with over the past three weeks of summer camp. They also got used to the fake high-fives and the distance hugs.

"It’s weird because you want to show emotion, you want to give high-fives, you want to give hugs and celebrate together," Girardi said. "But we’ve kind of gotten used to it, we’ve gotten used to the fake high-fives and all of that ... It’s definitely different."

Here are some other observations from the Phillies' opener:

Nola not great

Aaron Nola was starting his third straight opener, but this one didn't go very well for him.

Nola gave up a run in the third after Francisco Cervelli singled with one out. That was the first hit allowed by Nola. Miguel Rojas, the designated hitter who was batting ninth, followed with a single to send Cervelli to third. Cervelli scored on Jonathan Villar's sacrifice fly.

But Nola seemed to tire in the sixth when he surpassed 70 pitches. Jesus Aguilar hit a two-run homer with one out, and Corey Dickerson followed with a double to right. That ended Nola's night.

He went 5 1/3 innings, giving up four runs on five hits, while striking out seven. Nola threw 79 pitches.

"I felt good, honestly, throughout the whole game," Nola said. "Just a couple of spots where I was trying to get some balls in the zone, and it hurt me."

Where's the offense?

Girardi set up his lineup with Andrew McCutchen leading off, Rhys Hoskins batting second, Bryce Harper third and J.T. Realmuto fourth.

They combined to go 1-for-14 with six strikeouts.

The Phillies' offense came on Gregorius' solo homer in the fifth. The second run scored on an error when Villar, playing center field, dropped a routine fly ball hit by Jay Bruce that would have ended the inning.

Instead, Gregorius, who was on first base with a walk, hustled around the bases and scored while Bruce ended up on second. The error nearly proved to be costly as Scott Kingery followed with a potential home run ball that was just a few feet foul. Kingery then grounded out to end the inning.

Realmuto came up in the eighth as the potential tying run after Hoskins blooped a single into center and Harper walked with two out. Realmuto grounded out to the pitcher.

As a team, the Phillies had five hits, and Gregorius had two of them.

"We don't play as many games as we're supposed to," Gregorius said. "All these games count. We don't have a lot of time to catch up, and (we can't) fall too far back."

New rule hurts Phillies

MLB tweaked several rules during the offseason. One of them requires pitchers to face a minimum of three batters. That was done to prevent managers from replacing pitchers after just one batter, which slowed down the game.

So when Ramon Rosso replaced Nola in the sixth inning, Girardi had no choice but to wait for him to get through three batters. It didn't go well for Rosso, who was making his major league debut.

Rosso came on with a runner on second with one out and the Phillies trailing 3-1. He walked his first batter, then uncorked a wild pitch, putting runners on second and third. After a strikeout, he threw another wild pitch, giving the Marlins a 4-1 lead.

In previous seasons, Rosso would have come out of the game, but Girardi had to leave him in for one more batter. Garrett Cooper then ripped a double to center, scoring another run.

Finally, Girardi could replace Rosso, and he did.

search_result.title: Outbreak at Sussex prison on track to be state's largest
search_result.text:
Like governments across the country, Delaware prisons are seeing that coronavirus isn't going away.

After fighting back a large outbreak at the state's largest prison earlier this year — a fight that saw seven prisoners die from to the virus — the state's prison system is now battling an outbreak that will likely infect even more at its southernmost prison.

On Thursday, Delaware Department of Correction officials announced that 119 inmates at Sussex Correctional Institution south of Georgetown are infected. These are the first positive cases of inmates at that prison during the pandemic.

They are also the first results since correction officials announced earlier this week that each of the approximately 900 inmates at the prison will be tested for the virus. The number of infected is expected to rise as more of the inmate population is tested.

Thus far, officials have prioritized testing those over 60 years old and those with underlying health conditions that could be fatal in combination with the virus.

Officials said the virus is present in multiple housing units, making it harder to quarantine inmates that have not been exposed or to know who hasn't been exposed.

"Because the illness is present in several housing units we know that the number of positive test results will grow," said Claire DeMatteis, commissioner of the state's correction system on Thursday.

About a quarter of those that have tested positive are showing symptoms as of Thursday morning, officials said. The prison also has 10 correction staff currently positive for the virus, according to state figures.

The first hints of the outbreak among the prison population at SCI came last week when officials received a positive test from an inmate who had contracted the virus outside before being booked into the facility.

DeMatteis said the prison is working "aggressively" to contain the virus.

That includes moving three dozen inmates over 60 or who have underlying health issues to a vacant building at James T. Vaughn Correctional Center near Smyrna so they will not be exposed.

After denying inmates face coverings earlier this year, the prison is also providing masks to all 900 SCI inmates. Programs, visitation and the intake of new prisoners is also suspended for now.

PREVIOUSLY: Officials say prisoners won't get masks or release during COVID-19 fight

Officials have shuffled some inmates that tested positive to a special COVID-19 unit at Vaughn and said Thursday they are opening a special treatment center at SCI.

The outbreak at SCI will likely soon be confirmed to be the largest the state has seen at its prisons or any other state-run entity. A total of 128 inmates at Vaughn, the state's largest prison by population, tested positive for the virus earlier this year.

Currently, there are no active cases of coronavirus among the inmate population there.

Most recently, Joseph Slider, 60, was serving a 20-year sentence when he died of COVID-19 complications in late May. Slider had been at Vaughn since at least February when he was sentenced for killing his ex-wife during drug-induced hallucination.

The dead in Delaware prisons have averaged 71 years old and were mostly serving life sentences. Six of the seven had chronic health conditions that were compounded by the virus, officials said.

It's a death rate that is one of the highest in the country, according to statistics compiled by The Marshall Project, a non-profit news publication that has been tracking coronavirus cases and deaths in prisons across the country.

According to those statistics, Delaware has the fourth highest rate of death per capita compared to its overall prison population in the country.

Currently, three positive inmates are being treated in "stable" condition at local hospitals, officials said Friday.

While the growing outbreak in Sussex will be a primary focus, the correction system is also battling smaller clusters at other facilities. Morris Community Corrections Center currently has three inmates that have tested positive.

Three contracted staffers at Baylor Women's Correctional Institution have recently tested positive as well. Two staffers at a probation and parole check-in center in New Castle County have also tested positive. There are also ten staffers at Vaughn who have tested positive recently.

In all, 141 inmates across Delaware prisons have recovered from the virus in addition to about 80 workers, according to state officials.

search_result.title: Two Stones Pub opening Middletown site
search_result.text:
Two Stones Pub, a local chain offering a large variety of craft beers along with upscale pub fare, plans to open its sixth location later this year in Middletown.

Chef/owner Michael Stiglitz is leasing a 4,766-square-foot site at 840 Kohl Ave. in the new Hedgelawn Plaza off Middletown-Warwick Road.

The eatery will have a 648-square-foot, 40-seat outdoor patio.

Stiglitz has been on a roll since opening his flagship Two Stones brewpub in Chesmar Plaza near Newark in 2011.

Currently, there are Two Stones Pub locations in Brandywine Hundred and Hockessin. He also operates the Pennsylvania locations in Kennett Square and Jennersville.

In 2015, Stiglitz opened a brewery, 2SP Brewing Co., in Aston, Pennsylvania.

Two Stones Pubs offer salads, tacos, burgers, snacks like crispy Brussels sprouts with Sriracha mayonnaise, and entrees ranging from scrapple-stuffed meatloaf to vegan ravioli and seitan.

According to Joseph Latina, a broker with Patterson-Woods Commercial Properties who has worked with Two Stones since 2011, Stiglitz chose Middletown because of its "strong growth market" for his brand.

Latina said the Hedgelawn Plaza has high visibility, is centrally located and will have easy access off the new Route 301 Bypass Road.

The new Middletown site should be opened by the end of this year. It will have 200 seats. Visit www.twostonespub.com/

search_result.title: Georgetown Speedway sold to local investment group
search_result.text:
Georgetown Speedway has been purchased by an investment group including Brett Deyo, the track’s manager and promoter for the past five years.

“The agreement solidifies the future of the Sussex County property for auto racing,” Deyo said in a news release Tuesday night.

Until now, Deyo, of BD Motorsports Media, had been operating the track under a lease agreement with owner Seacoast Investors. That limited the improvements he could make at the track, he said.

“The purchase will allow us to seriously evaluate the needs of the facility and make upgrades for the future,” Deyo said.

He will continue to manage the track.

The four-parcel property north of Georgetown, surrounded on three sides by Route 113, Speedway Road and Bethesda Road, changed hands Dec. 30, 2021, according to Sussex County records. Seacoast Investments sold the land to Parkada Investments for $1.55 million.

Parkada Investments’ registered agent is James Parker of Millsboro, owner of Jim Parker Builders. When approached, Ken Adams, owner of several Georgetown businesses including Stockley Materials and Melvin L. Joseph Construction Company, also confirmed his involvement in the speedway purchase.

Adams is the grandson of Melvin Joseph, who first opened the track in 1950. Neither he nor Parker immediately returned calls for comment.

RELATED:Delaware dirt tracks draw in new racing fans. Now they're making moves to keep them

Dover Downs converting to Bally's Dover Casino Resort as parent company continues to grow

Seacoast Investments doesn’t have an individual registered agent. Deyo said previously the group is comprised of six people that live out of state. They planned to develop the race track property, Deyo said, but that never came to fruition.

Georgetown Speedway’s 2022 season will begin March 10 with Melvin L. Joseph Memorial Weekend. The headlining race will offer the largest purse in Delaware dirt-track history, according to Deyo. Winnings range from $25,000 for first place to $1,000 for 16th.

search_result.title: Will URI, Bryant football teams outplay low preseason expectations?
search_result.text:
The University of Rhode Island and Bryant both have some climbing to do if the preseason Coastal Athletic Association football predictions play out as released Wednesday morning.

The Rams were tabbed eighth and the Bulldogs were picked 15th while making their debut in the new 16-team league. Head coaches voted on both order of finish and individual all-conference teams.

More:With departure of veteran QB, who will be under center for URI football this fall?

More:Bryant football feeling ripple effects from shakeups at top-tier conferences

URI is coming off a 6-5 campaign overall and a 4-4 mark against league foes. The Rams open their 2024 schedule against Holy Cross on Aug. 31 and will be looking to make it four straight winning seasons under coach Jim Fleming. That includes a 13-11 record against conference opponents — it took URI nine years to win that many league games from 2011-19.

“Obviously, I want to put up my numbers but I just want to win,” URI linebacker AJ Pena said. “I want to get that CAA title. That is so important on my mind.”

Pena was one of three preseason all-league selections for the Rams, joining defensive lineman Westley Neal Jr. and punt returner Gabe Sloat. Wide receiver Marquis Buchanan was named an honorable mention selection after a breakout 2023 campaign. URI will replace four-year starting quarterback Kasim Hill and a host of experience across the offensive line entering its first game with the Crusaders.

“It’s hard,” Pena said. “I’m not going to lie. We always question how we approach certain things or situations.“We’re just trying to be all-around great at football. That takes caring about other people as well.”

Bryant matched the Rams with a 6-5 mark last season and went 4-2 in the Big South-OVC conference. The Bulldogs join a league that put four teams into the FCS playoffs and find themselves playing a more regional schedule. They visit Delaware for an Aug. 29 opener under the lights.

“We’re playing on edge this year,” Bryant tight end Marc Taglieri said. “We’re going to be violent and we’re going to bring it to the guys in this new conference.”

Defensive lineman Michael Otty was named to the all-conference team after collecting seven sacks and 12 tackles for loss last season. Bryant will also be breaking in a new quarterback after Zevi Eckhaus announced a transfer to Washington State. The Bulldogs will host URI in the regular-season finale on Nov. 23.

“This spring was probably the most competitive and intense spring we’ve had offensively,” Taglieri said. “Every day was a dogfight.”

Reigning cochampion Villanova was selected to top the league with nine first-place votes. The Wildcats feature the preseason Offensive Player of the Year in quarterback Connor Watkins, who totaled more than 3,000 scrimmage yards and 30 touchdowns last season. Reigning cochampion Richmond was picked second and received a lone first-place vote.

Albany and Delaware were tabbed third and fifth, respectively, with both receiving three first-place votes. They sandwiched William & Mary, which was picked fourth. Elon was selected sixth along with safety Caleb Curtain, a returning All-American and the league’s preseason Defensive Player of the Year.

New Hampshire tipped the Rams for seventh place and Towson followed URI in ninth. Monmouth, Campbell, Hampton, Maine and North Carolina A&T were tabbed ahead of Bryant in the bottom half of the standings. Stony Brook was picked last after closing 0-10 in 2023.

search_result.title: Pope's visit bumps up UD-Villanova matchup in 2015
search_result.text:
Kevin Tresolini

The News Journal

NEWARK – An unusual early-season matchup with Villanova, resulting from Pope Francis’ September visit to Philadelphia, highlights the University of Delaware’s 2015 football schedule announced Thursday.

Villanova-Delaware has been a regular-season finale since the 1999 season, with the Battle of the Blue trophy awarded the winner since 2007. The 2015 matchup, however, comes Sept. 19 at Villanova.

Pope Francis is visiting Philadelphia Sept. 22-27 and Villanova had scheduled Parents Day for its Sept. 26 home game against nonconference foe Penn. Knowing there would be significant interest in the papal visit, leaders at Villanova, a Catholic school, decided Sept. 26 was not suitable for a special event such as Parents Day, explained Colonial Athletic Association associate commissioner Scott Meyer.

Villanova will still play Penn in its only nonconference home game Sept. 26. But Parents Day was moved to Sept. 19. Each CAA school is permitted to choose one date on which it is guaranteed a home game, Meyer said, and that was Villanova’s.

“Delaware was the only available home opponent to put there,” Meyer said, citing conflicts caused by CAA schools’ schedules.

The CAA schedule, in which each of the league’s 12 teams plays eight games, will feature the same opponents in 2015 as in 2014 but at the opposite sites. That means Villanova was locked in to play Delaware, William & Mary, Maine and Richmond at home in 2015.

“It’s a one-year thing,” Meyer added, referring to Delaware-Villanova resuming their season-ending encounters in future years.

The 2015 game is presently scheduled at Villanova Stadium. The last two meetings in which Villanova was the home team have been played at PPL Park in Chester, Pennsylvania, home of Major League Soccer’s Philadelphia Union, after the conclusion of the MLS season. The MLS season will still be ongoing in September, however.

Delaware-Villanova was actually played in September from 1994 through 1998. Delaware has played Villanova 47 times, more than any other opponent except for West Chester. The Wildcats have won seven of the last eight and lead the series 25-21-1 going into their Nov. 22 encounter in Newark.

Next season, Delaware will play home CAA games against William & Mary (Oct. 3), New Hampshire (Oct. 24), Albany (Nov. 7) and James Madison (Nov. 14). It’ll be the first home CAA game against New Hampshire since 2006, though the Wildcats did visit for a NCAA 2010 playoff.

In addition to Villanova Sept. 19, the Blue Hens travel to Rhode Island (Oct. 10), Towson (Oct. 31) and Elon (Nov. 21).

Delaware’s three nonconference games in 2015 are at home against Jacksonville (Florida) on Sept. 5 and Lafayette on Sept. 12 and at North Carolina on Sept. 26.

The Hens’ open date is Oct. 17.

FCS returns to an 11-game schedule in 2015. Twelves games were permitted in 2013 and 2014 simply because of the extra Saturday that fell between Labor Day and Thanksgiving those years. The next 12-game season for FCS is 2019.

search_result.title: University of Delaware wins pivotal CAA football matchup vs. Elon ...
search_result.text:
The University of Delaware football season reached a crossroads on Saturday and the Blue Hens went in the proper direction.

There are still numerous potential obstacles ahead, beginning with this week’s trip to New Hampshire. But the Blue Hens (4-2 overall, 2-1 Colonial Athletic Association) are back on track.

Down 10-0 early and 16-14 through three quarters, the Hens demonstrated the necessary offensive firepower and defensive toughness to rule in the decisive fourth quarter.

That made them 28-16 winners over Elon, which had risen to No. 5 in the STATS media Top 25 national FCS poll after last week’s 27-24 win at James Madison.

“We felt this would be a very pivotal game in our season,” coach Danny Rocco said.

Delaware took the lead with 7:01 left on Pat Kehoe’s 23-yard touchdown pass to Vinny Papale on third-and-4. It closed a six-play, 68-yard drive that also included a pass-interference penalty against Elon.

After the Phoenix were forced to punt after three incomplete passes, Kani Kane’s 2-yard TD run with 4:02 to go closed a six-play, 53-yard march that was all runs, including Kane’s 32-yard gallop.

The defense then stopped Elon again on downs to lock up the win.

Elon lost its starting quarterback to a knee injury in the first quarter, though its backup had seen significant previous duty while doing more running than passing. In addition, the CAA’s leading rusher, Malcolm Summers, didn’t play because of an injury.

But the Phoenix had plenty of other formidable features, including an offensive line with 133 career starts and a sturdy defense. Yet Delaware, despite three first-half turnovers that could have been its downfall, managed to overcome a shaky start and score a big win.

Five takeaways from Saturday:

Sensing the stakes

The Blue Hens understood the critical nature of this game in perhaps determining their long-term fate, even though many challenges remain.

The victory should provide confidence moving forward. Delaware has five games left, including three against teams presently in the Top 25.

“It felt that way from really, probably Monday, or Sunday night when we started breaking down film,” senior inside linebacker Troy Reeder said of the game’s huge importance.

“Guys just saw it as what it was. It was No. 5 coming in to play us at home and we love playing at home. I think guys did a really phenomenal job preparing all week and hopefully the rest of our schedule we continue to prepare like we’re playing a top-five team.”

Regaining the run

Kane’s 124 yards on 19 carries, Delaware’s first 100-plus effort since Kane’s 106 in the opening-night loss to Rhode Island, highlighted a resurgent day for UD’s running attack.

Delaware averaged 4.7 yards per carry against Elon. The Hens came in averaging 3.0.

“We are physical,’’ Rocco said. “We thought we’d be able to get some movement in there, knock them around a little and sure enough in the fourth quarter that was somewhat the difference in the football game.”

DeJoun Lee, a smaller, quicker, more elusive runner, was again effectively mixed in to complement the powerful Kane.

But Delaware also had success lining up in its wildcat formation with Joe Walker at quarterback, his old position before moving to wideout. From that, Delaware unleashed a variety of plays.

“We played a complete game up front,” Walker said, crediting the offensive line’s role in the effort. “They went to war every single play.”

Home-field advantage

Saturday’s crowd of 19,924 was the largest in three years, since 19,924 attended the game against New Hampshire in 2015.

Certainly, Family & Parents Weekend always brings a larger gathering and it’s still nothing like the 2000s, when sellouts and 20,000-plus throngs were the norm.

But it was impressive and added to a great game-day atmosphere.

“There were some times out there today,” Rocco said, “that we had so much energy in that stadium that it was just joyful for me and I’m hoping it was joyful for our fans because there was excitement and energy. Our kids were playing hard, and it was a big factor in the game there at the end.”

Rocco mentioned the fanfare that followed Noah Plack and Jack Dinicola stopping Elon’s returnman at the Phoenix 18 on Delaware’s kickoff following its go-ahead TD.

“Our sideline went nuts. The fans went nuts, crazy,” Rocco said. “And this is a kickoff play. It was just all right there for us. I do think that’s what we’ve all been kind of searching for.”

Gotta be more careful

Delaware was fortunate Elon didn’t take greater advantage of the Hens’ sloppy start that included three first-half turnovers. Delaware’s 64 yards in penalties were also well above its 41-yards-per-game average.

“That made it more difficult than it needed to be but it gave us that opportunity to rise up and we certainly did that,” Rocco said.

Future situations may not be as forgiving.

Delaware now goes to New Hampshire, where it hasn’t won in 15 years. Though the Wildcats (1-5, 0-3) are likely to see their string of 14 straight years in the NCAA playoffs end, they are no easy task anywhere.

“I do think this team is getting better,” Rocco said. “I think that we learn from our experiences, we’ve learned from our hard defeats. This team has been through a lot of adversity. This team has been challenged, doubted, disbelieved and we keep coming back every day, going to work, focusing on the next day, staying together, staying united.”

Numbers game

Delaware limited Elon to 289 total yards – they’d averaged 415.4 — after giving up 608 at Richmond and 527 at North Dakota State.

Reeder, the CAA’s leading tackler, had 15 more, including five for lost yardage in another inspired effort.

Joe Walker passed for 37 yards, ran for 17, had 25 yards receiving and 84 on kickoff returns. No wonder NFL scouts have taken notice.

The Blue Hens won despite having no takeaways but making three turnovers.

search_result.title: Zanor column: Khaleed Exum-Strong back on the sidelines at NFA
search_result.text:
Just thought I’d empty out my reporter’s notebook while thinking that someday Des Moines, Iowa, is going to have the same basketball shrine-like quality and sheen as French Lick, Indiana …

Strong returns to NFA

It was great to see former Norwich Free Academy football and wrestling star Khaleed Exum-Strong working with the Wildcats running backs at a recent practice. Strong, who looks like he can play on Sundays, has joined first-year coach Dylan Schroth’s staff this fall as an assistant coach.

“He’s one of the best modern running backs in NFA history,” Schroth said. “He’s holding up some high standards. He’s got those guys working hard every day.”

The Wildcats are going to rely on the “Four Horsemen” group of junior Luchen Lercius and sophomores Magnus King, Xavier Sebastian, and Jha’Meer Quinn-Haskins to carry the football after the graduation of Gage Hinkley, who is playing at Division I Rhode Island as a freshman linebacker.

ECC defensive coordinators are probably still having nightmares thinking about the Wildcats running back tandem of Marcus Outlow and Exum-Strong, who helped NFA reach the 2012 Class LL state championship game (a loss against Xavier).

Two years later, Exum-Strong rushed for 2,100 yards as NFA rolled to another Class LL title game appearance (a loss against Southington). His football accolades included two-time All-Conference, and All-State honors. He spent a prep year at Trinity Pawling and was selected All-Conference and All-New England.

“We’re just so fortunate to have a young man who exemplifies what we preach in terms of the hard work and dedication. He’s a role model,” former NFA football coach Jemal Davis told The Bulletin in 2014. “Everything that you want in a son, you see in Khaleed. He doesn’t take anything for granted, he’s not critical of anybody, leads by example. Those are the qualities that you want in your leader.”

Exum-Strong’s wrestling exploits at NFA included ECC, State Open and New England championships.

“The whole thing about Khaleed - he is like a gladiator,” former NFA wrestling coach Kirk Jenkins told The Bulletin in 2014. “He always lives (for) and rises to the occasion.”

In 2021, Exum-Strong earned the Northeast-10 Conference Most Valuable Player award after rushing for a league-best 140.6 yards per game and nine touchdowns in NE10 play, as well as a remarkable 7.3 yards per carry for Assumption College (Worcester, Mass.).

Exum-Strong finished his career (2017-2021) at Assumption second in school history in both rushing yards (2,862) and touchdowns (35).

College hoops bonanza

The place to be for college basketball fans this fall isn’t the Palestra, Pauley Pavilion, Rupp Arena, Allen Fieldhouse, Cameron Indoor Stadium or the Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx. It’s the Mohegan Sun Arena in Uncasville.

The Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame announced that tickets for all regular-season college basketball games at Mohegan Sun are now on sale. (Tickets for the Basketball Hall of Fame Enshrinement exhibition game on Oct. 14 between UConn and Rhode Island will go on sale Friday, Sept. 13.)

The 10,000-seat Mohegan Sun Arena will host 20 college basketball games this season.

"Mohegan Sun will be an exciting home for hoops during the fall and winter, as we’re set to host both the UConn Men & Women, Providence, UMass, and so many other great college programs,” Jeff Hamilton, president & general manager of Mohegan Sun, said in a press statement. “Our partnership with the Basketball Hall of Fame has been remarkable, and we can’t wait to showcase this powerhouse lineup of basketball inside Mohegan Sun Arena, beginning October 14!”

More:Boys high school soccer players to watch in 2024

For more information, please visit hoophall.com.

Some of my favorite matchups include the Saturday, Nov. 23, tripleheader featuring Vermont vs. Delaware, Yale vs. Fairfield, and Temple vs. UMass; and a December 14 doubleheader of Providence vs. St. Bonaventure and my alma mater, Fordham, vs. Bryant.

Yankee Conference football

With Sacred Heart and Merrimack playing for the mythical Yankee Football Conference championship on Nov. 16, I’ve also decided to give the New England-based league, which folded in 1996, a rebirth. UConn’s 50-7 season opening loss against Maryland was the final straw.

You say “Big 12.” I say “Yankee Conference.”

Each week I will update my hypothetical 2024 Yankee Football Conference standings and crown a football champion at the end of the year. WEEK 1: Rhode Island 1-0; Maine 1-0; Delaware 1-0; New Hampshire 0-1; UMass 0-1; UConn 0-1.

Wild Card hopes fading

As of Friday afternoon, the slumping Boston Red Sox are 5.5 games out of the third and final Wild Card spot. The Sox were 70-70 entering Friday and their cold bats are showing no signs of heating up. This impending September swoon is going to be tough because I liked this team. The Sox have exceeded expectations. Until now.

But I'll be OK. I don't mind wearing a Minnesota Twins hat during the postseason.

More:Girls soccer players to watch in 2024

STUCK IN THE 70s

Loyal reader and Fordham classmate Stephen Feeley, who played basketball and baseball at Swampscott High School in Massachusetts, reminded me that Fran Sheehan, the bassist for rock and roll band, Boston, was a Swampscott High graduate who played on Big Blue’s 1968 Class B state championship basketball team. Sheehan’s teammate was legendary football, basketball and baseball star Dick Jauron.

Jauron also led the Big Blue football team to a state title in 1968 and was selected a Parade High School All-American. Jauron starred at Yale as a running back and safety and was named a First Team All-American in 1972. He was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 2015.

Jauron played eight seasons as a safety in the NFL with the Detroit Lions (1973-1977) and Cincinnati Bengals (1978-1980). He was selected to the Pro Bowl in 1975.

Jauron became an NFL coach after retirement as a player. His head coaching career (1999-2009) included stints with the Chicago Bears, Detroit Lions, and Buffalo Bills. He was named the NFL Coach of the Year in 2001 after guiding the Bears to a 13-3 record.

Jimmy Zanor is a sportswriter for the Norwich Bulletin and can be reached at jzanor@norwichbulletin.com. Follow him on Twitter@jzanorNB.

search_result.title: 12 wishes for University of Delaware football's 2018 season
search_result.text:
The University of Delaware begins preseason football practice Wednesday afternoon, so the in-state athletic season that generates the most fervent passions among First State fans is fast approaching.

The Blue Hens kick off the 2018 campaign Aug. 30 at home against Rhode Island. It’s Delaware’s first opener against a Colonial Athletic Association rival since starting the 2007 season at William & Mary.

The anticipation leading to the onset of another UD football season is like the eagerness that accompanies the countdown toward Christmas. That'll be evident in the hundreds who'll flock to a couple Saturday scrimmages in Delaware Stadium, anxious for a sneak peek.

With that in mind, it’s time for a wish list – 12 things it'd be good to see during this Delaware football season.

1. Give the ultimate tribute

College Football Hall-of-Famer Tubby Raymond died last December at age 92. What better way to honor the man whose teams won 300 games as Delaware coach and is likely the state’s most celebrated sports figure than, on the first play of the 2018 season, line up in Raymond’s signature Delaware Wing-T offense. I can see a pulling guard now, and the Rhode Island defense, duped by the Wing-T’s mischievous misdirection, wondering who on earth has the football. Tubby Raymond Field would thus be truly consecrated in its namesake’s spirit.

2. End the postseason famine

The NCAA established postseason championships for football beginning in 1973. In 2010, when Delaware reached the FCS title game and lost to Eastern Washington, it was the Blue Hens’ 20th postseason appearance in 33 years and seventh title game. Until then, Delaware had never gone more than three years (1983-85) without qualifying. That playoff absence has now stretched seven excruciating years, which once would have seemed as utterly unfathomable as a U.S. presidential candidate likely conspiring with a foreign adversary to get elected. Delaware nearly made the playoffs last year under first-year coach Danny Rocco. The Hens are better suited to land in the postseason this year, and must end that drought to reconnect with a shrunken fan base.

3. Come see

An opening night sellout may be too much to ask at 22,000-seat Delaware Stadium, which is slated to undergo a much-needed and long-overdue face-lift beginning early next year. There hasn’t even been a crowd of 20,000-plus since the William & Mary game in 2013 (21,010). This year’s home schedule isn’t particularly star-studded and there are only three home games after Sept. 15, which is odd. The Hens should be worth watching, and a 20,000-plus opening-night turnout isn’t a fantasy.

4. Defend at the FargoDome

Delaware will be put to the test in its Sept. 22 visit to North Dakota State, which has won six of the last seven FCS titles. The UD offense will try to run plays in the deafening roar inside the 19,000-seat FargoDome. It’ll be courteously quiet for the Bison offense though, until it makes a big play. Led by what could the best linebacker corps in FCS, Delaware should have a staunch defense after finishing 10th nationally in scoring defense (16.8 ppg) last year. Let’s see it silence the Bison and turn this much-anticipated visit into the trip of a lifetime.

5. Don't miss these two

Delaware’s football history is loaded with individual players who were worth the price of admission. Some of those more recent Blue Hens are in the NFL now. Two who could have a chance to join them are inside linebacker Troy Reeder, the Salesianum graduate in his third season after transferring from Penn State, and safety Nasir Adderley, whose leaping one-handed interception at Towson last year made national highlights.

6. Make passing grades

The Blue Hens have been the CAA’s worst passing team the last three seasons. Last year’s 124.5 air yards per game was their best average in that span, though it was still paltry. Delaware doesn’t have to exhibit incredible aerial firepower. It must have more explosiveness and better balance with what should be a formidable run game.

7. Seek steady play at QB

Wish 6 leads to this one: Delaware needs more consistent and mistake-free play at quarterback, where the addition of position coach Al Wood should be a boost. Wood is a former head coach at James Madison, Buffalo and Florida A&M and has guided quarterbacks in the NFL and at FBS programs. J.P. Caruso is a returning starter and Boston College transfer Darius Wade out of Middletown High arrives with impressive credentials. But don’t rule out dark-horse Pat Kehoe, a fourth-year junior who has appeared in just one career game.

8. Get jolts from Joe, Jamie

While it didn’t work out for Joe Walker in 2½ years as starting quarterback, his move to wide receiver opens up a realm of electrifying possibilities for the Blue Hens, who watched him get 165 all-purpose yards last year at Maine – 158 in the first half – while playing a variety of positions. Delaware coaches need to find ingenious ways to unleash his talents. Come to think of it, same goes for Jamie Jarmon, the former Indian River High quarterback standout and minor-league baseball player who is now a senior wideout loaded with potential.

9. Try two-back attack

The Blue Hens have a slew of formidable running backs, led by last year’s leading rusher Kani Kane, 1,000-yard career rushers Thomas Jefferson and Kareen Williams, impressive 2017 freshman Khory Spruill and newcomers DeJoun Lee and Andre Robinson, a potential Penn State transfer. Not that we’re advocating a full-time return to the Wing-T, but more two-back sets would seem potentially appropriate and tough to defend.

10. Win the close ones

It’s not always who has the best players or best team. It’s who executes and wins the close ones. Delaware’s 7-4 finish last year was highlighted by dramatic wins against Stony Brook 24-20 and Richmond 42-35 in overtime and lowlighted by the 18-17 loss at Towson and 28-7 defeat at Villanova, the latter two setbacks coming against teams that finished 5-6. There need to be less of the latter and more of the former, though life in the CAA ensures many down-to-the-wire games.

11. Turn over a new leaf

The best league trip and most potentially pivotal road game that UD fans shouldn’t miss is Oct. 20 at New Hampshire. Durham will remind you of Newark as a splendid college town and it should be particularly eye-catching in late October (The hotels are in nearby Portsmouth, also very appealing). The Wildcats have made 14 straight NCAA playoffs and may be in contention with Delaware for a spot this time. Oh, and Delaware hasn’t won here since 2003, its NCAA title season, which happens to be the last time UNH didn't reach the postseason. If Delaware wants to get back in the playoffs, it may have to win here.

12. Vanquish Villanova

The only athletic prowess Villanova should be flaunting over Delaware is in basketball. Yet Delaware has lost six straight and 11 of the last 12 football skirmishes against its long-time rival, a run of ineffectiveness nearly as startling as that playoff absence. Come Nov. 17 at Delaware Stadium, where Villanova has not lost since 2004, the Blue Hens need to take care of business in a way they didn’t in 2017. There may be a playoff berth riding on it.

Contact Kevin Tresolini at ktresolini@delawareonline.com. Follow on Twitter @kevintresolini.

search_result.title: 8 burning questions for Delaware football, including: Can a younger ...
search_result.text:
One football season ends and, at places such as the University of Delaware, thoughts immediately turn toward the next.

The Blue Hens certainly wished the 2018 campaign had lasted a bit longer. Last week’s 20-6 loss at James Madison in a first-round FCS playoff game meant Delaware didn’t make it to December.

But the Hens (7-5) did reach the NCAA playoffs for the first time since 2010, a noteworthy accomplishment.

That made the season a success, though three losses to end the year, including another exasperating defeat against Villanova, certainly left some a bit unsatisfied, especially considering the experience on this team.

Delaware only won fewer than seven games on five occasions under coach Tubby Raymond from 1966-2001. Times are different now, and the back-to-back seven-win seasons are Delaware’s first since 2010-11. Before that it was 2003-04.

Making it three straight will be a tough challenge considering the Blue Hens’ youthful makeup in 2019, but the prospect excites coach Danny Rocco.

“There is a certain eagerness with youth that is, I think, contagious,” he said. “There’s a lot of guys that know they have a chance to be the guy. When you turn the clock back a year, a lot of guys probably didn’t feel they had a chance to be the guy, as they looked in their position rooms.”

Delaware will need all the zeal it can muster next year against a 12-game schedule featuring a visit to Pitt, a home game against FCS power North Dakota State and the usually perilous Colonial Athletic Association minefield.

Here are eight questions lingering from this year and pointed toward next season, with a particularly interesting take from Rocco on future UD defenses.

1. Was this a successful season?

For the most part, certainly.

The Blue Hens returned to the FCS playoffs and were, until the final regular-season Saturday, in contention for the CAA championship. En route, they scored wins over Top 10 teams Elon and Towson during a five-game win streak.

They were then dealt a very difficult first-round playoff matchup at James Madison, where the defense was up to the task and the offense wasn’t in a 20-6 JMU win.

“I was really proud of how hard our players played last Saturday,” Rocco said. “We played better on defense. It doesn’t mean we didn’t play hard on offense.”

The spate of errors that doomed Delaware in a 21-19 season-opening loss to Rhode Island was a disappointment, as was Villanova’s continued dominance in the regular-season finale.

Rocco felt a solid foundation was laid for future success.

2. What about the quarterback situation?

Pat Kehoe completed just 13 of 32 passes for 116 yards with two late interceptions and was sacked five times while often under a heavy rush at JMU. His 49.3 completion percentage for the season is lowest among CAA starters and he's ninth in QB efficiency.

But Rocco said the partially torn ACL that Kehoe suffered at New Hampshire on Oct. 20 played a large part in that. It was clear he wasn't the same quarterback in November he was in September.

“Late in the year when people rushed our passer,” Rocco said, “they had no concern about pass-rush lanes because they felt the quarterback was not going to escape.”

Kehoe started the season strong and gave the Hens the downfield passing attack they’d lacked.

Kehoe was named Colonial Athletic Association Offensive Player of the Week after the Blue Hens’ 40-36 comeback win over Towson. He completed 18 of 32 passes for a career-high 305 yards and four touchdowns.

“Pat will be at his best and I think we all have an image of what that will look like,” Rocco said. “Pat at his best is pretty good and certainly capable of leading this team.”

In addition, Nolan Henderson came off the bench when Kehoe got hurt against Villanova and showed an ability to extend plays. Rocco called the Smyrna High grad’s showing “very much attention-getting.”

Freshman Anthony Paoletti also made a positive impression, including when it appeared he might be pressed into service at JMU.

Rocco said neither Kehoe’s knee or Henderson’s ankle injury, which kept him out at JMU, will require surgery.

3. What about that running game?

Delaware is 11th among CAA teams in rushing offense (105.3 yards per game) and yards per carry (3), awful numbers for a school with a traditionally strong ground attack, though that number is skewed by sacks.

Kani Kane being sidelined the last two games with a knee injury didn’t help. Dejoun Lee (4.9-yard average) had a strong debut season. Penn State transfer Andre Robinson, who gained 62 yards on 23 carries, will likely figure in more next season.

It did seem odd that Delaware never called on seniors Kareem Williams and Thomas Jefferson, though Jefferson was switched to H-back after skipping spring practice with the intent of not returning.

Jefferson is Delaware’s 20th all-time leading rusher with 1,802 yards. Williams is 38th with 1,406. And they gained most of those yards from 2014-16, often when opponents knew the Hens were going to run.

“All the conversations were had,” Rocco said, adding that catching, blocking and protecting are as important as running in deciding who plays.

Others had a “more complete” set of abilities, he said. “Certainly respect the careers both Kareem and Thomas have had here,” Rocco said.

4. Who’ll be the new offensive coordinator?

Matt Simon will not return, Delaware announced Tuesday, and Rocco said he’s mainly combing the FCS ranks for a potential replacement. There are already qualified available candidates with CAA ties.

“Guys that might not be totally married to one system,” Rocco said of the kind of person he’s seeking, “but have a little bit of history of being able to adapt, adjust, use their personnel.’’

He said he’d also consider those on his own staff, which includes former James Madison, Florida A&M and Buffalo coach Alex Wood, who is quarterbacks coach.

There certainly could be other staff changes. Cornerbacks coach Nick Rapone left the staff because of family matters. He’s expected to continue coaching elsewhere.

5. Talking about an evolution?

Asked if Colby Reeder would stay at his outside linebacker “Kat” position, where he sometimes lines up as a defensive end, Rocco said more than expected.

“We are really looking at transforming our defense,” he said.

While the 3-4 alignment is likely to remain the basis, “more four-down structure is probably likely,” he said.

“It’s personnel driven,” Rocco said. “We are deep in the D-line. We’ve got some really talented, proven players there.”

Delaware had trouble getting to the quarterback this year. But the Hens often went with a four-man line at JMU. They netted three sacks — giving them 16 on the year, ranking 11th of 12 teams in the CAA — while frequently benefiting from the pressure they unleashed.

Where Reeder ends up remains to be seen, but there’ll be a domino effect, Rocco said, moving from the line back.

6. What position area faces the biggest turnover?

The secondary graduates all four starters, though cornerback Nijuel Hill was a starter most of last year and part of this year before K.C. Hinton took over. Though Hill struggled in some games giving up long passes, “he didn’t have a bad year,” Rocco said.

Justis Henley and Amonte Strothers are promising cornerbacks who will be redshirt freshmen next year (Henley did play in the maximum four games that allowed him to retain the year of eligibility). Concord grad Brian Dennis is also back.

At safety, freshman Noah Plack, who played in three games, is joined by Tim Poindexter, expected to return after missing 2018 with a knee injury, Joey Carter, Andrew Pawlowski and C.J. McAnally. Outside linebacker Kedrick Whitehead could be moved to safety.

Delaware also has a promising flock of receivers capable of stepping in for seniors Joe Walker, Vinny Papale and Jamie Jarmon, and tight end Charles Scarff.

7. Which Blue Hens will get NFL looks?

Nasir Adderley has been selected for the Senior Bowl and is likely to get drafted. The safety is the only player in FCS with 160-plus tackles and at least nine interceptions the last two years. That kickoff return for a TD at New Hampshire didn’t hurt either.

Linebacker Troy Reeder, fifth nationally with 131 tackles, has certainly earned a chance, too. His year as a Penn State starter helps.

But others — Scarff, Walker, Papale and linebacker Ray Jones, in particular — could get a chance as well.

8. Outlook for next year?

Delaware loses more than two dozen seniors and two-thirds of its starters, mostly on defense.

But the offense has some talent to help offset the departures, though improvement on the offensive line is a must. The defense will have to rely on its front and hope a young crew can develop fast behind them.

Delaware won’t likely be viewed as a CAA title contender next year, but will aim to prove otherwise.

“I’m very optimistic,” Rocco said, “though I do recognize the challenges that will be presented to us. But I’ve got a lot of good young talent.”

UPDATE: The Oklahoma Sooners snapped a three-game losing streak Saturday with a 59-14 win against the Maine Black Bears in Week 10 of the college football season.

NORMAN — The grind of OU's inaugural SEC schedule takes a break Saturday when the Sooners take on Maine.

The game will kick off at 11 a.m. and stream on ESPN+ and SEC Network+.

The contest was originally scheduled to kick off at 1:30 p.m., a nod to the Sooners' usual home start time from 1962-95 but expected inclement weather led OU to move the start time up.

The Sooners have played seven FCS teams since the start of the 1999 season, outscoring those teams by a combined score of 433-29.

Jackson Arnold is expected to make his second consecutive start at quarterback, after throwing for 407 yards and three touchdowns with no interceptions over the last two games.

More:OU football smashes Maine as Sooners move one win away from bowl eligibility | 5 takeaways

OU vs Maine score updates

◻ 1 2 3 4 F MAINE 7 0 0 7 — 14 OKLAHOMA 7 28 14 10 — 59

More:How did OU football walk-on Jacob Jordan end up with Sooners?

FINAL: OU 59, Maine 14 | Sooners move to 5-4 on season

The Sooners outgained the Black Bears 665-251.

Up next for OU is a trip to Missouri next Saturday.

—Jeff Patterson, Staff writer

More:OU football grades vs Maine: Jovantae Barnes, game-time change get high marks for Sooners

6:17 left in 4Q: OU 59, Maine 14 | Xavier Robinson gets on the scoreboard

Former Carl Albert star Xavier Robinson touched the ball on seven consecutive plays, capped by a 4-yard touchdown run.

Robinson had a 46-yard reception earlier on the eight-play, 75-yard drive.

—Jeff Patterson, Staff writer

More:OU football injury update: Brent Venables 'hopeful' Deion Burks, Jalil Farooq return soon

9:38 left in 4Q: OU 52, Maine 14 | Nick Laughlin scores on 5-yard run

Nick Laughlin scored on a 5-yard run for Maine's first score since the opening drive, but it was set up with a 47-yard catch by Joe Gillette.

—Jeff Patterson, Staff writer

12:37 left in 4Q: OU 52, Maine 7 | Zach Schmit field goal extends Sooners' lead

Zach Schmit made a 24-yard field goal to cap a 13-play, 58-yard drive for the Sooners.

Michael Hawkins Jr. went 2-for-3 passing for 14 yards on the drive, while adding 30 rushing yards on three carries.

—Jeff Patterson, Staff writer

End 3Q: OU 49, Maine 7 | Michael Hawkins Jr. takes over at quarterback

Michael Hawkins Jr. has taken over.

On the final drive of the third quarter, Hawkins replaced Jackson Arnold and quickly gained 30 yards on three carries as the Sooners are threatening to start the fourth.

OU is outgaining Maine 576-124 after three.

Maine managed just nine yards in the third quarter.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

3:56 left in 3Q: OU 49, Maine 7 | David Stone sack forces punt

OU’s young defenders are getting a chance.

David Stone sacked Maine quarterback Carter Peevy on third down to force a seventh punt from the Black Bears.

Maine has not had a drive last more than three plays since late in the second quarter and hasn’t gained more than 24 yards on a drive since their first drive of the game.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

6:20 left in 3Q: OU 49, Maine 7 | Jackson Arnold connects for TD pass with Kaden Helms

OU’s offense keeps rolling along.

Kaden Helms caught his first career touchdown pass, a 9-yarder from Jackson Arnold.

The Sooners have scored touchdowns on seven of their last eight drives.

Arnold is 15 of 21 for 224 yards and two touchdowns.

The reception was just the second of Helms’ career and the first since 2022 vs. Nebraska.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

12:40 left in 3Q: OU 42, Maine 7 | Jovantae Barnes scores another TD

Jovantae Barnes found the end zone again.

Barnes scored on a 19-yard touchdown run, his third score of the day, keeping up his career day.

Barnes bounced around the outside on the play, finding room to run along the east sideline.

Barnes has equalled his career high in scoring. He rushed for two touchdowns and caught a touchdown pass in the loss to Tennessee earlier this season.

Barnes has 13 carries for 186 yards.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

14:16 left in 3Q: OU 35, Maine 7 | Robert Spears-Jennings forces, recovers fumble

OU’s defense finally forced a turnover.

Robert Spears-Jennings forced a fumble by Jaharie Martin and recovered it himself in the opening minute of the season half to give the Sooners the ball in Maine territory.

The fumble recovery was OU’s first defensively since Sept. 21 vs. Tennessee.

The Sooners recovered a fumble last week vs. Ole Miss but it was the Rebels’ defense that turned it over after OU had fumbled earlier in the play.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

0:34 left in 2Q: OU 35, Maine 7 | Jovantae Barnes scores another TD

The Sooners keep moving the ball on the ground.

Jovantae Barnes had another big drive, capping a two-minute drill drive with an 8-yard touchdown run, his second score of the game.

Barnes now has 158 yards on 11 carries, a career high.

Barnes’ previous career high was 108 yards, in the 2022 Cheez-It Bowl loss to Florida State.

OU has rushed for a season-high 236 yards and passed 400 total yards for the first time this season.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

2:00 left in 2Q: OU 28, Maine 7 | Danny Stutsman record first sack

Danny Stutsman’s sack on third down — the first sack by either team in the game — helped give the Sooners the ball back with a chance to stretch their lead before half.

OU has held Maine to 117 yards — 68 of those on their opening drive.

Stutsman and Billy Bowman have four tackles each to lead the Sooners.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

3:16 left in 2Q: OU 28, Maine 7 | Jackson Arnold connects with J.J. Hester for 90-yard TD

OU finally has a massive passing play.

Jackson Arnold hit J.J. Hester for a 90-yard touchdown pass, the Sooners’ longest of the season by far, to put them up by three touchdowns with just more than three minutes remaining.

OU’s previous long passing play of the season was Michael Hawkins Jr.’s 60-yarder to Hester against Auburn.

Arnold is 7 of 12 for 153 yards and a touchdown and has run for 30 yards and a score.

The Sooners are outgaining Maine 352-114.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

3:39 left in 2Q: OU 21, Maine 7 | Black Bears pin Sooners deep

OU’s defense held strong again, forcing a fourth consecutive punt.

This time, though, the Sooners won’t have nearly as good of field position.

Maine’s punt went to the 10, giving the OU offense a long field to work with with less than four minutes to play in the first half.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

6:46 left in 2Q: OU 21, Maine 7 | Jovantae Barnes, Jackson Arnold extend Sooners' lead

Jovantae Barnes’ strong day continues.

Barnes broke off a 29-yard run on the first play of the drive after Maine’s shanked punt, then Jackson Arnold carried it in from a yard out two plays later to put the Sooners up by two touchdowns.

Barnes has seven carries for 121 yards.

The Sooners have rushed for 199 yards, already their second-best rushing performance of the season.OU ran for a season-high 220 yards in the opener against Temple.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

7:35 left in 2Q: OU 14, Maine 7 | Sooners take over at Maine 37

The Sooners finally forced a three-and-out.

And after a shanked punt, OU will start in Maine territory.

Aidan Cadogan’s punt went just 23 yards, giving the Sooners the ball at the Maine 37.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

8:37 left in 2Q: OU 14, Maine 7 | Sam Franklin fumbles in red zone

The Sooners were rolling offensively.

But on second-and-9 from inside the Maine 20, Jackson Arnold flipped the ball to Sam Franklin on an option play and Franklin couldn’t handle it, kicking the ball forward where it was recovered by Maine at the Black Bears 16.

The turnover was the first of the day for the Sooners, who have multiple turnovers in each of their last three games.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

10:56 left in 2Q: OU 14, Maine 7 | Penalties doom Black Bears' drive

OU’s defense appears to have found a rhythm.

The Sooners forced Maine to punt from deep in their own territory.

Maine was flagged for holding on back-to-back plays, though the Sooners declined after a 6-yard loss on a pass and an incomplete pass on third down.

The Sooners are outgaining the Black Bears 171-92.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

More:How much is OU football paying Maine for Week 10 game in Norman?

13:44 left in 2Q: OU 14, Maine 7 | Jackson Arnold, Sooners take first lead

Jackson Arnold hit Jacob Jordan for a 6-yard gain on fourth-and-3 in Maine territory, keeping the drive alive for Taylor Tatum’s eventual 1-yard touchdown run.

Tatum carried on each of the final five plays of the drive, including a 17-yard run to give the Sooners first-and-goal.

OU has rushed for 132 yards, already their fourth-best rushing game of the season.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

3:58 left in 1Q: OU 7, Maine 7 | Sooners' defense gets back on track

After a rough start, OU’s defense buckled down on their second drive.

Maine picked up 10 yards on the first drive before the Sooners stopped the Black Bears on back-to-back run plays, before Carter Peevy was sent scrambling on third down.

Peevy picked up 7 but still, the Black Bears had to punt.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

7:07 left in 1Q: OU 7, Maine 7 | Jovantae Barnes, Sooners tie it up

OU answered quickly.

Jovantae Barnes broke off a 74-yard run to put the Sooners in position, then two plays later, Barnes took it in from two yards out to tie the game.

Barnes was initially ruled to have scored on the run, but replay revealed he was down at the 1.

After Jackson Arnold was stopped for a loss, Barnes carried it in.

The 74-yard run was the longest for the Sooners during the Brent Venables era.

It was the Sooners’ longest run since Caleb Williams’ 74-yard touchdown run against Iowa State in 2021.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

7:59 left in 1Q: Maine 7, OU 0 | Carter Peevy carves up Sooners' defense

Maine quarterback Carter Peevy broke off a 40-yard run on OU’s defense to set up a touchdown pass on the next play and give the Black Bears an early lead.

Maine’s offense is known for their deliberate approach.

The Black Bears didn’t disappoint their in their opening drive, earring up nearly five minutes of clock with the drive.

Maine took advantage of a fourth-down defensive delay of game penalty on the Sooners and converted on a third-and-7 to keep the drive alive.

Peevy broke off his long run on a zone read play, then hit tight end Cooper Heisey for a 3-yard touchdown on the next play.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

12:42: OU 0, Maine 0 | Sooners' offense flat on first drive

OU’s offense did not get off to a promising start.

The Sooners picked up a first down quickly but then stalled, having to punt after just six plays.

Jackson Arnold’s lone pass on the drive was incomplete.

—Ryan Aber, Staff writer

Pregame update: Sooners missing three offensive linemen
